title: Good franchisee restaurant
text: It is on the first floor with a narrow access from roadside shop. The ambience is ordinary. The food was reasonably priced and tasty. The place is recommended for Bengali cousine.

title: Journey into india's colonial past
text: The garden is beautiful and well maintained. The lakes and waterbodies are pleasing to the eye. The memorial is a huge imposing structure.

title: Beautiful Temple
text: It is a beautiful and popular tourist site. Crowded , on the banks of the river. The image of kali as mahishasurmardini is pleasing to the eye.

title: A Wasted Masterpiece
text:
The marble palace lies in a corner which is desolate with narrow approach roads and vehicle inaccessible bylanes. Photography is not allowed which prevents popularisation. It is managed by unfriendly staff who give you an impression of being unwelcome. The upkeep is also poor which does not leave a good impression on ones mind. But inspite of these none too informidable drawbacks, the museum is packed with artefacts par excellence. There is wooden work, the highlight amongst which is a one piece statue of Victoria. There is marble, china, glass and brass in three roomfulls. The walls are adorned with reputed painters' works and india's own raja raviverma also finds a place.
It is urgently necessary for the ASI to take this over and convert it into a well maintained museum of international attraction and repute.

title: Church or sun temple
text:
This is a highly recommend site in Cusco. It is a church Santo Domingo which proudly proclaims to have built itself after demolishing the most pious inca site that was a sun temple. The Christian component has beautiful paintings of Mary and Domingo which are pleasing to the eye.
The inca component, which is what is actually promoted on the tourist circuit, is negligible. One will see nothing here that one may not see on a tour of Machu Picchu and the sacred valley, which are purely Inka sites.
So go if one likes the same monotonous church paintings seen the world over. If you want the Quechua/Inka circuit, qorikancha is not the place to go.

title: Avoidable
text: We saw this as it was close by. It has a 10 sol entrance, which is a complete waste of money. It is promoted together with Cusco cathdral as it has no value on its own. Avoid even if you have time on hand.

title: Good meeting and socislising place
text:
Plaza de armaz is the most important landmark in Cusco. The central park has the statue of inka king presiding over the square. Here one gets a beautiful view of the surrounding hills on which Cusco is situated. Lord Jesus Christ looks down on you from one corner.
Cusco cathedral adorns one side and to its left is the church of triumph and natural history museum. Here one will see hotels, shops and hawkers galore. Do rest in the garden in the evenings.

title: Poor companion
text:
The ticket of 70 sols comes combined with that of sacsayhuaman. This decidedly is a joint promotion for poor tourist attractions which are avoidable. Apparently it is inca site for water temple.
There is a water spout. Does not make an enjoyable visit.

title: A beautiful place
text: One can understand this place only with a guide. Otherwise it is just stones and slides. Mayukmarca is the eye of the puma that is cusko. It gives a good photo.op of the city. Volcanic rocks hav created slides for children to enjoy. 'Echo point' was a good shouting match. Snake on the stone is the god of underworld. Burial ground, chairs of inka and khoya, toad god of the Quechua and the tunnel for water flow all have to be shown by an expert. In all a very good experience.

title: Not upto the mark
text:
The facility provided a two room enclosure for 3 adults. It was spacious with a balcony which opened to the outside and gave adequate light and ventilation. The appliances were substandard. The TV cable would disengage spontaneously and required repeated plugging in. The fridge had low cooling. The toilet seat was loose. The electrical heater for food was also not good enough. These are just suggestions for the owner to improve upon.
On the plus side, the hotel is located close to bus, port, airport, malls for comfortable living.

title: Knossos sidekick
text: The ticket is sold along with Knossos palace by paying just 1 euro extra. It is recommended to visit the place after seeing the palace. The museum is on 2 floors. The ground has all artifacts recovered from Knossos. The bee pendant is the highlight. Scripts, statues, vessels, jewellery, funeral objects, decorative pieces are the artefacts on display. The first floor has all the original frescoes from the walls of Knossos.

title: Minoan Citadel
text: It's a euro 1.70 bus ride from Herakleion bus stop to the Knossos palace from bus station A by bus 2. The entry is euro 15. The site is beautifully explained on billboards with accurate directions for seeing. The ruins are of a palace with storage/garbage pits in beginning. The courtyard, walkway are nicely delineated. The throneroom has pictures of mythical bird.lion creatures. The Queens room has dolphins. The prince with lillies, pot carriers are other beautiful depictions. The bull on east facade is the highlight.

title: Comfortable ride
text: The ferry ride was at 9pm from Piraeus Athens, run by ANEK services. The ferry set out in time. The sea was compassionate , hence the ride was smooth and nothing untoward felt inside cabin. No motion sickness. The boat arrived in time at Herakleion at 6.30am. The disembarkation was uncomplicated and one could just walk out of the port. There is a complimentary coffee and juice from the company at the exit gate, something that most passengers are unaware and hence remains unutilized. There is also an ticket upgradation to cabin, available after the boat sails, whenever available.

title: Comfortable stay
text: The place is managed by 2 pleasant ladies, Georgia and S--. We were in an apartment overlooking metaxurghio circle and metro station. The sculpture of the fallen aviator was a pleasant companion. The room was spacious and comfortable. There was a fridge and toaster, but no microwave for heating. The bed for the third occupant was a children's bed, unfit for a six footer. Room service was deficient as the housekeeper made only one appearance in a 5 day stay.there are good restaurants, supermarket and money changers in vicinity. The facility is lovely if small changes suggested above are made.

title: Primary Museum in Athens
text: It is spread on 2 storeys, ground plus one. Majority of artefacts are on ground floor. Noteworthy are the bronze statues of Zeus and Perseus and a horse rider. The marble statue of Aphrodite and Eros is also beautiful. The rest is all average. Good to see this one to get a feel of the art in Greece.

title: Temple to Athena
text: An imposing structure. Only the outer wall of pillars remain, 8 in one direction and 16 in the other. A must see for all visitors to Greece.

title: Trip to the remote past
text:
The monument is huge. The entry door itself is imposing. As soon as one enters, one gets a mind numbing view of the Parthenon. It spreads east.west. only the external pillars remain, the internal temple of Athena is completely destroyed.
Erechtheion is the other structure that is preserved. The gallery to south with supports in lady form are pleasing to eye.
Theatre of dionysus and odeon of herodes atticus are the other two places of performance.

title: Museum with the monument
text: It is the most visited site after seeing the monument. The artefacts are limited. They are original pieces recovered from mt. acropolis. At 10 euros, the fee is steep. Can be avoided or should be included with the monument in same fee.

title: On top of Athens
text: Mt lycabettus deserves a visit. Get down at evangelismos metro station and walk. Right from the station one's walk is slow uphill. It is best to take the most trodden path rather than the funicular, as the treasures reveal slowly. The view from the top is stupendous. Acropolis is also visible, but at a distance and not with clarity to the naked eye. A church and a restaurant cater to the devout and the famished.

title: Visit to navel of earth
text: The tour started in time. The hotel pickup was smooth. Katia Liapi was our guide and Lukas, the driver. The lady was erudite and regaled us in chaste english about Greek history and mythology. She showed us around the museum and introduced us to the best pieces. Even the archeological site visit was eventful. We were given adequate time to explore the venue ourselves. In the end we also listened to the music written 25 centuries back. Lukas was a good driver and the journey smooth.

title: Disputed history
text: This land is under seige, with half a dozen checkpoints and a hundred soldiers guarding. The walkway has steel netting with monkeys snarling on the outside. One can see the sanctum from 50 ft through the grill. It is a tent with a few idols that you can't identify from the distance. Can't feel very pious and holy under the circumstances.

title: The abode of the lady
text: Given by kaikeyi to sita when she came to ayodhya. The building is beautifully maintained. A must visit, if one is in ayodhya.

title: The first station of call
text: One has to take permission from hanuman, before one visits ram lalla. The temple is in a fortress (garhi), requiring a steep climb. The idol is accessible. The atmosphere is pious with a ram dhun chanting continuously.

title: Nice paitings
text:
A collection of 9 to 10 life-size paintings commissioned by the nawabs and drawn by European painters.
Each painting has a nawab and the building that he created, in the background. Gives a lesson in history.

title: Garden to see
text: A nicely landscaped area with lakes, cycling and walking tracks, benches to relax and trees to cool the surroundings.

title: A tall monument
text: Situated close to the 2 imambaras, the clock tower is a good photo-op. The clock is working even after 138yrs. There is a water body in front which improves the ambience.

title: A decent eating place
text: It is a franchisee with eateries in various areas, the best being lalbaug. The hotels are popular and the pricing is pocket friendly. The fare is quite delicious though a bit oily, but then it is mughlai. They cook in the open though, which may irk a finicky patron.

title: Trip down the memory lane
text:
This is the place where the mutiny of 1857 started. The tell tale signs are visible all over the ancient buildings. Built from 1775 to 1800 to accommodate the British resident, the structures are opulent and suggestive of the lavish lifestyle of its occupants.
The museum on campus shows some nice pictures.

title: A gargantuan egotrip
text: The monument is built over many acres. On the plus side, it is beautifully landscaped. There are stupas and there are gardens. The elephants erected in scores gives it a pharoic appearance. There are statues erected of a living person, while the doyens of social transformation are humbly scattered to the periphery. The surrounds are cool and serene. The nighttime lighting is also excellent.

title: Petit, but beautiful
text:
This is much better preserved than its larger namesake. The courtyard has waterworks with a bridge. There are tajmahalesque structures on either side. The earthing for the main gate on either side is through beautiful metallic golden ladies.
The main building has Islamic calligraphy on its walls.

title: Door of benevolence
text:
Constructed by the nawab to give labour to his people during a famine. Both it's facades are different. On one side are 3 orifices while on the other is the famous single door.
Made with lentil as one of the ingredients, it also has clove replicas all over the structure.

title: Visit to an historic site
text:
This is the leader amongst the 5 sites in the area. It necessitates a guided tour, no individual adventure is permitted. The reason being the labyrinth or bhulbhulayya. The intricate passages will challenge any newcomer and one will get lost in narrow, dark passages.
The gallery on the top gives a beautiful view of the surrounds.
Worth a visit, but poorly maintained by the trust.

title: Enjoyable guided tour
text: We dropped in at the town hall behind st Paul's church and learned that there are guided tours at 11am and 1pm for 10 people each. The management was gracious to accommodate us. The tour was conducted by an elderly gentleman who gave us the history of Melbourne and the town hall. Showed us the meeting rooms and the chair of lord mayor. We toured the auditorium and the balcony and the reception room with a history of having hosted dignitaries like Nelson Mandela and the royals. A piano with association to Beatles was a photo opportunity.
